bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, May 20, 1941

div1.p: Hench discusses his speech for the upcoming unveiling of the Cornwell portrait and suggests guests to be invited by Kellogg.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, May 20, 1941
div1.opener:
May 20, 1941
Mr. George A. Kellogg
257 Cornelison Avenue
Jersey City, N. J.
My dear Mr. Kellogg:
div1.p:
I still think you are making a mistake in not having Ireland or some
similarly prominent man give the main talk, but inasmuch as I am chosen, I will
accept with pleasure and will do my best. I am anxious to know at your earliest
convenience the general setup of the program, the approximate number of guests,
etc., so that I can “feel out” my expected audience and arrange the type of talk
that will be suitable.

How many other speakers will there be? Is Miss Reed responding with a
few words? Is Kissinger to talk? Kissinger is a nice old fellow, but has very
little schooling and from the standpoint of grammatical construction, etc. speaks
poorly. I would suggest, therefore, that you notify him that he will merely be asked
to respond briefly to an introduction, expressing his pleasure at being there and, as
he usually does, telling how glad be is to have had a modest part in the experiments
done by the physicians, etc. I warn you not to have him talk extensively because he
never uses notes and is inclined to ramble. Is someone going to say anything about
your researches to make the painting accurate? Do you wish me to touch on that briefly
in passing? Did you have in mind that I would use a certain amount of the talk that
I used at Washington and Jefferson, a copy of which I believe I sent you? Of course,
it will have to be re-arranged and the emphasis will not be as much on Lazear, but on
the whole group. Is anyone else going to tell the general story of the yellow fever
investigation?

My present tentative plan for the talk (which is subject to change) is to
start out with a few words expressing my appreciation, as one physician, for the
stimulus that I as a medical man have gotten from your series of paintings. I
thought that I would touch upon the zeal with which you have undertaken this job and
mention the care and thought that you and Cornwell have put into making it accurate.
I would then suggest that perhaps many of the audience did not know or might have
forgotten the details of the story and for their sake I would briefly review it. I
would then give a short running account of what happened, including my recent discov-
eries of Lazear's deliberate rather than accidental infection, mentioning (only to
pass over it almost immediately) our discovery of the present whereabouts and condition
of Camp Lazear. Then I would evaluate this in terms of public health and present
defense, all of this very briefly, and then end on an inspirational note. I must
know at once, however, whether this overlaps any speaking assignments to any other
invited guest. It would seem nice to have Miss Reed and Mr. Kissinger introduced
after my talk, that the audience will have been freshly told of the significance
of their contribution. Are Van Etten, Cummings or Ireland to be there for it?

You were kind enough to suggest that you would invite some of my friends.
I am sorry that my wife won't be alon, but I have four friends in Akron, Ohio who
might like to come--Dr. and Mrs. Theodore Bliss, 236 N. Highland Avenue, and Mr. and
Mrs. L. M. Seiberling, 97 Mayfield Avenue. Dr. Bliss was formerly here at the Clinic
for some years. Mrs. Seiberling was my wife's maid of honor at our wedding and Lu
is the son of the Seiberling Tire folks. He is, of course, not a professional and
perhaps doesn't rate admission to this affair.

Are you going to invite Dr. Robert P. Cooke, Lexington-Rockbridge Health
Department, Lexington, Virginia? You remember he participated in the experiments as
did Captain Thomas M. England, 1715 East Long Street, Columbia, Ohio. Mrs. James O.
Cawne, 2540 Massachusetts Ave., Washington, D. C. is Lazear's cousin. Dr. H. E.
Jordan, Dean of the Department of Medicine, University of Virginia, has been much
interested in the yellow fever story. You will of course send an invitation to Mrs.
Lazear. Another cousin is Mr. John Lazear, 922 South Negley Avenue, Pittsburgh, Pa.
A son is Mr. William Huston Lazear, 1325 Fifteenth Street, Sacramento, California.
A cousin of Lazear's is Mrs. Charles P. Orr, 6101 Howe Street, Pittsburgh, Pa.
Some of these relatives might well run up from Pittsburgh. Dr. James E. Peabody,
281 Lowell Avenue, Newtonville, Massachusetts, and his daughter, Miss Elizabeth
Peabody, Department of Biology, Wilson College, Chambersburg, Pa. have been long
interested in this story and did much to get the pension and Congressional Medal for
the participants. I think you have Mrs. Walter Reed's address and the address of
Reed's son. Dr. Wilbur A. Sawyer, Director of The Rockefeller Foundation, New York
City, is of course the greatest authority on yellow fever today, and he is quite
familiar with the yellow fever story. He was my co-speaker at the Washington and
Jefferson affair. Miss Frances B. Seth, 4511 Windsor Mill Road, Woodlawn, Baltimore,
Maryland, is another cousin of Lazear. Don't consider any of these guests mine. If
you invite them they should be your guests.

Three or four of my other friends, if you need them, would be Dr. John
Garvin, Jenkins Arcade, Pittsburgh, and Dr. and Mrs. Frank Edmundson, 5317 Fifth
Avenue, Pittsburgh. Dr. J. D. Heard, my former Professor of Medicine, 121 University
Place, Pittsburgh, is much interested in medical history, and Dr. W. W. G. Maclachlan,
527 Medical Arts Building, Pittsburgh, was also a former teacher of mine.

Please do not consider it necessary to invite these friends of mine, but
some of them might come up from Pittsburgh since they may be attending the A.M.A.
anyhow. I shall be grateful if you will rush the requested information at your
earliest convenience.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
